instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3209: What is 820-3209? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPVCORE_S0_CPU: What is PPVCORE_S0_CPU? This is the primary power rail for the CPU that powers the CPU, known as CPU vcore. Without this, the machine will be braindead. .
definitions.PP1V05_S0:
What is PP1V05_S0? The PP1V05_S0 power rail is for various components on the logic board that require a 1.05V supply voltage in the S0 (on) state. This voltage rail is likely to be used by the CPU (for VCCIO), PCH (Platform Controller Hub).

.
definitions.PP1V8_S0: What is PP1V8_S0? PP1V8_S0 is a power rail that is present when the machine is in an S0 state, meaning it is fully turned on, not sleeping or hiberating .
definitions.PPVCORE_S0_AXG: What is PPVCORE_S0_AXG? This is vcore going to the CPU’s integrated graphics processor for CPUs that have an integrated GPU. When this is missing on a device that has an integrated GPU and no discrete GPU, it usually means either no screen is detected, or the GPU integrated into the CPU is dead..
definitions.CPUIMVP_PGOOD: What is CPUIMVP_PGOOD? CPUIMVP_PGOOD is a signal from the CPU VCORE buck converter IC that indicates CPU power is good which is necessary to create PM_S0_PGOOD..
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .
definitions.ALL_SYS: What is ALL_SYS? This is a typo of ALL_SYS_PWRGD When you see ALL_SYS, assume they meant to type ALL_SYS_PWRGD.
definitions.CPUIMVP_VR_ON: What is CPUIMVP_VR_ON? CPUIMVP_VR_ON is a signal that tells the buck converter responsible for PPVCORE_S0_CPU to turn on and create CPU vcore voltage. This comes from ALL_SYS_PWRGD – once ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present, CPUIMVP_VR_ON will be present. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no vcore
threads.message:
Board history: Liquid, attempted repair.

All the usual rails are fine.

Been all over testing this board am lost at this point.


L7550 to ground 1.5 ohm
L7510 to ground 2 ohm (get the same on donor boards but nothing working to reference)

<SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> = 0v
<SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_AXG</SIGNAL> = 0v
<SIGNAL>CPUIMVP_TON</SIGNAL> = 0.7v
<SIGNAL>CPUIMVP_PGOOD</SIGNAL> = 0.5v


<SIGNAL>PPVCCAS_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> = 0.9v
<SIGNAL>PP1V05_S0</SIGNAL> = 1.5v
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_S0</SIGNAL> = 1v8



What do I need to be looking for please?

threads.message: <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS</SIGNAL> should of course be there. There is a rail missing.....

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no vcore
threads.message:
[QUOTE="dukefawks, post: 22756"]<SIGNAL>ALL_SYS</SIGNAL> should of course be there. There is a rail missing.....[/QUOTE]

Sure, I did miss one. <RESISTOR>R2805</RESISTOR> was missing from the board (Not a no stuff right?) Fan spins now.
Now there is no chime, no mouse LED, no PRAM reset.... Now to find the issue there.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no vcore
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> now 3v3. PP1V5 is now present.

Still no vcore

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no vcore
threads.message: Yeah and how did that resistor end up missing? Inspect for more damage, there is more you missed.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no vcore
threads.message:
[QUOTE="dukefawks, post: 22802"]Yeah and how did that resistor end up missing? Inspect for more damage, there is more you missed.[/QUOTE]

eBay board. And yes clearly.

This board is really doing my nut.

Could this be SPIROM? Missing PM signal? PCH? Fucked up trace / Resistor / cap?

Here are few measurements but what do I need to be looking for please..... Any clues?

<SIGNAL>ALL_SYS</SIGNAL> =3v3
<SIGNAL>CPUIMVP_TON</SIGNAL> = 0.35v
<SIGNAL>CPUIMVP_VR_ON</SIGNAL> =3.3v
<SIGNAL>CPUIMVP_PGOOD</SIGNAL> = 0.06v

<SIGNAL>CPUIMVP_BOOT1G</SIGNAL> is 4.8v
<SIGNAL>CPIIMVP_BOOT1_RC</SIGNAL> is 4.8v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no vcore
threads.message: Ebay garbage. Any missing/damaged resistor can cause this. Why do you pick up this garbage?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no vcore
threads.message:
[QUOTE="dukefawks, post: 22966"]Ebay garbage. Any missing/damaged resistor can cause this. Why do you pick up this garbage?[/QUOTE]
I'll send it back for a refund.
